subsection_content_2: .  The Union health ministry confirmed earlier this week that two districts, Purnia and Madhepura, both in the Indian state of Bihar, have detected outbreaks of the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 virus.  This is the first time in 2013 that H5N1 has been detected in India.  338 chickens died at a government poultry farm in Purnea within a few days. In Madhepura, 800 chickens have died after coming in contact with the deadly virus.  Throughout the state, precautionary steps including culling, border monitoring, and banning the sale of chicken and eggs, are all in place to help prevent further outbreaks.  The Patna Zoo in Purnea has announced that it has increased the frequency of sanitation work to reduce the risk of possible introduction of the virus to the zoo’s collection of birds and animals.
subsection_content_1: .  The Australian Department of Agriculture and Food confirmed earlier this week that a duck, which was part of a backyard flock of 71 ducks and chickens, was infected with low-pathogenic avian influenza in Perth, the capital of Western Australia, The duck has been sick, but while testing was being conducted, the flock was moved to a second location containing additional birds. The authorities believe that this outbreak poses no threat to humans, about 100 ducks and chickens at both affected areas were culled to help prevent further outbreaks.  Additionally, authorities are monitoring the area and urging owners of backyard poultry to keep their birds away from wild birds, keep their backyards clean, and to alert their local vet if they encounter any sick or dead birds.
